<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 374, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 462, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Test scores, \(X\), have mean 54 and variance 144. The scores are scaled using the formula \(Y = a + bX\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants and \(b > 0\). The scaled scores, \(Y\), have mean 50 and variance 100. Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 151, 94, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
35% of a random sample of \(n\) students walk to college. This result is used to construct an approximate 98% confidence interval for the population proportion of students who walk to college. Given that the width of this confidence interval is 0.157, correct to 3 significant figures, find \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 228, 94, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 821, 247]]<|/det|>
Jack has to choose a random sample of 8 people from the 750 members of a sports club.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 259, 154, 278]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 259, 707, 278]]<|/det|>
Explain fully how he can use random numbers to choose the sample.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 259, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
Jack asks each person in the sample how much they spent last week in the club café. The results, in dollars, were as follows.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 330, 715, 350]]<|/det|>
15 25 30 8 12 18 27 25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 370, 153, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 370, 650, 388]]<|/det|>
Find unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 151, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 655, 419]]<|/det|>
Explain briefly what is meant by ‘population’ in this question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 419]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 447, 96, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 446, 635, 465]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[383, 470, 608, 510]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}k\mathrm{e}^{-x} & 0\leqslant x\leqslant 1,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 530, 153, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 529, 326, 554]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{\mathsf{e}}{\mathsf{e} - 1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 566, 151, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 566, 353, 585]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{E}(X)\) in terms of e.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 613, 96, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
Records show that the distance driven by a bus driver in a week is normally distributed with mean \(1150\mathrm{km}\) and standard deviation \(105\mathrm{km}\). New driving regulations are introduced and in the next 20 weeks he drives a total of \(21 800\mathrm{km}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 675, 156, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 675, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
Stating any assumption(s), test, at the \(1\%\) significance level, whether his mean weekly driving distance has decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 692, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 721, 153, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 721, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
A similar test at the \(1\%\) significance level was carried out using the data from another 20 weeks. State the probability of a Type I error and describe what is meant by a Type I error in this context.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 752, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Ranjit goes to mathematics lectures and physics lectures. The length, in minutes, of a mathematics lecture is modelled by the variable \(X\) with distribution \(\mathrm{N}(36, 3.5^2)\). The length, in minutes, of a physics lecture is modelled by the independent variable \(Y\) with distribution \(\mathrm{N}(55, 5.2^2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 135, 153, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total length of two mathematics lectures and one physics lecture is less than 140 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 183, 153, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 183, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
Ranjit calculates how long he will need to spend revising the content of each lecture as follows. Each minute of a mathematics lecture requires 1 minute of revision and each minute of a physics lecture requires \(1\frac{1}{2}\) minutes of revision. Find the probability that the total revision time required for one mathematics lecture and one physics lecture is more than 100 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 233, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 276, 92, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
The numbers of men and women who visit a clinic each hour are independent Poisson variables with means 2.4 and 2.8 respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 323, 156, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 323, 532, 342]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, in a half-hour period,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 185, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 348, 655, 365]]<|/det|>
2 or more men and 1 or more women will visit the clinic,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 348, 920, 365]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 371, 180, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 371, 569, 390]]<|/det|>
a total of 3 or more people will visit the clinic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 373, 920, 390]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 402, 153, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 402, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, in a 10-hour period, a total of more than 60 people will visit the clinic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 418, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
